Expectation1: Adhere to professional standards and operational protocols.
Situation1: An email has arrived with an optional sign-up for a future professional development seminar, and you should respond to that.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They think about joining Sunday worship when time allows
Story: As a subway operator, my days are tightly scheduled, every minute accounted for. This morning, an email popped up from management—an optional sign-up for a professional development seminar next month. They say it’s not mandatory, but I know how these things go; those who show initiative are remembered. The seminar, of course, is on a Sunday. I glance at the calendar and feel a familiar pang. Sundays are for church, for worship and fellowship, for reconnecting with my faith and my community. I haven’t been as regular lately, always telling myself I’ll go when time allows, but the truth is, work keeps creeping in. My supervisor expects us to be proactive, to show commitment beyond the tracks. My pastor, and my own conscience, expect me to honor the Sabbath, to be present in the pews, not just in spirit. I stare at the email, cursor hovering over the RSVP button, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding a piece of me I’m not sure I can give.
